Movie.title: Sita Sings the Blues
Movie.summary: An animated version of the epic Indian tale of Ramayana set to the 1920s jazz vocals of Annette Hanshaw.

item.text: Paley's beguiling, consistently inventive visuals and sly yet melancholy tone are about as warm and winning as heartbreak-fueled empowerment gets.
item.author: Michelle Orange

item.text: Captivating, mesmerizing, spellbinding -- I'll throw everything in the movie-critic book at this animated feature by Nina Paley
item.author: J. R. Jones

item.text: An almost indescribable pleasure from Brooklyn-based cartoonist and animator Nina Paley. The film, dazzling and poignant and five years in the making, retells the ancient Indian epic The Ramayana from a gentle but insistent feminist perspective.
item.author: Ty Burr

item.text: Constitutes an irrefutable argument for classic 2-D animation as a viable, vibrant low-budget arthouse medium for adults.
item.author: Ronnie Scheib

item.text: A spellbinding film that charms with its quirkiness in almost every sequence.
item.author: James Plath

item.text: The more love changes the more it stays the same. History itself falls prey to love in this delightful retelling of the Ramayana.
item.author: Ron Wilkinson

item.text: ... beautiful and often densely detailed images ...
item.author: Andy Klein

item.text: A very creative and poignant animated film about the heartbreaks experienced by a Hindu goddess and a contemporary woman who share the universal pain and sadness that accompany the end of an intimate relationship.
item.author: Frederic and Mary Ann Brussat

item.text: It's akin to watching creativity just explode onscreen -- part abstract, part musical, part improvisation-style comedy, and, most compellingly, all inspired by real-life pain.
item.author: Jeffrey Chen

item.text: The story makes little sense to those unfamiliar with Indian culture and literary traditions, but it is made accessible for westerners by the use of a kind of Greek Chorus of shadow puppets who help interpret the story.
item.author: Robert Roten

item.text: [Filmmaker Nina] Paley adapts the original 1922 story, The Ramayana, by Valmiki and, wearing many hats, produces a work that is fun, entertaining, educational, colorful and imaginative.
item.author: Robin Clifford

item.text: Romantic breakups have provided inspiration to artists through the ages, but never have lemons been made into such a sparkling lemonade as Paley's done here.
item.author: Laura Clifford

item.text: The story shifts effortlessly between the two-dimensional collage style of the narrator segments, the classical artistic design of the Rama-Sita story, the pencil sketch style of the modern story, and finally Hanshaw's musical numbers in a two-dimensional
item.author: Rubin Safaya
